answers.answer: I'm assuming George was tested for diabetes, thyroid and anemia. If you're not sure which tests he had done, ask for a copy of his records. (It's good to keep a home file anyway.) If any of those were not done, ask for them to be done.If he were my husband, I would want him to also have a sleep study to rule out any sleep disorders disrupting his sleep stages, even if not waking him. Poor sleep caused me to wake up nauseous, and felt weak and sleepy all time. May be a long shot, but worth a try. The sleep study will monitor his heart, brain waves, and respirations overnight, so all that could be good info to have.If these things are done and you have no answers, ask your docs what is next. They can't know how serious you feel this is unless you continue to tell them. With every thing they rule out, ask them what the next thing is they'll be looking for. Please let us know how things progress.

question: My husband is 55 years old.  For many years, and many times throughout every year, he's been getting sick with colds, the flu, etc.  It's as though his tolerance level has always been low, or his immune system is weak.  Since early May of this year, he's been becoming increasingly weak and extremely lethargic.  However, his blood results came out normal.  Today, he's very sick, lightheaded and nauseas.  However, the doctors are baffled.  We have no one else to turn to, and we have no idea how to cure this.  He's been out of work for a long time and is trying to get back on his feet, but he becomes increasingly tired throughout the day.  He ends up sleeping most of the day, taking three hour naps, and waking up tired.  Does anyone have any suggestions?  I'd appreciate any advice.  Thank you.  Patti & George
title: We Don't Know What's Wrong - Doctors are Baffled
